HEA_composition.approach: continuous composition-spread thin-film libraries (ML1, ML2, ML3)

phase_information.ML1: mixed regions: fcc, fcc + hcp, and hcp

synthesis.method: combinatorial co-sputtering from five elemental targets (Ag, Ir, Pd, Pt, Ru)
synthesis.notes: 342 measurement areas (MAs) synthesized simultaneously on each ML

XRD.purpose: identify phase (fcc vs hcp) across the composition library
XRD.finding: ML1 contains mixed phases; ML2 and ML3 are purely fcc

EDX_mapping.purpose: verify continuous composition gradients across ML
EDX_mapping.finding: smooth spatial composition variation consistent with library design

electrochemical_performance.measurement_method: scanning droplet cell (SDC) with linear sweep voltammetry (LSV)
electrochemical_performance.activity_descriptor: current density at 820 mV vs RHE
key_findings: Predicted and experimental activity maps agree well when using Model III
Most active CSS compositions outperform Pt thin film in the low-overpotential region
Activity trends are robust to potential choice because LSV curves do not cross in the relevant range
electrochemical_performance.reproducibility: ML2 re-measured after 90° rotation; identical activity trends obtained

theoretical_computations.surface_model: 100×100 atom fcc slab (3 layers) randomly populated by Ag, Ir, Pd, Pt, Ru

descriptor_basis.Model_I: *OH binding on on-top sites (optimum = 0.1 eV weaker than Pt)
descriptor_basis.Model_II: *O binding on hollow sites (optimum = 0.2 eV weaker than Pt)
descriptor_basis.Model_III: co-adsorption of *O and *OH with neighbor-site blocking

theoretical_computations.current_model: Koutecký–Levich formalism with site-resolved current ji(U)
theoretical_computations.dataset: ≈20,000 DFT-predicted binding energies used to train linear regression
theoretical_computations.optimization: sequential least squares programming to maximize predicted activity
conceptual_conclusion: On CSS surfaces, on-top (*OH) and hollow (*O) sites do NOT scale as on pure metals
Including adsorbate–adsorbate interaction and site blocking (Model III) is essential
Active surface emerges from local site heterogeneity + neighbor blocking effects
